questions.text: Which is the best parameter to analyze hypoxic hypoxia?

choices.text: Partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2)
Partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2)

questions.solution:
Hypoxic hypoxia is characterized by low partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2), while other parameters like partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2) may remain normal.

Ventilation–Perfusion Imbalance:

  • The patchy ventilation–perfusion imbalance is the most common cause of hypoxic hypoxia or hypoxemia.
  • If alveoli are not ventilated but perfusion is present - blood passing through that alveoli remains unoxygenated.
  • When this unoxygenated blood mixes with blood from normal or overventilated alveoli, there is a right to left shunt created.
  • This results in reduced partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood  (PaO2) i.e., hypoxemia and consequently hypoxia.

Note:

  • Hypoxemia can be defined as a condition where arterial oxygen tension or partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is below normal.
  • Hypoxia is defined as the reduction of oxygen supply at the tissue level, which is not measured directly by a laboratory value.

Scenario 1:

  • Generally, the presence of hypoxemia suggests hypoxia i.e. if there is less oxygen in blood, O2 supply to tissues will also be reduced.
  • But, in case of cyanide poisoning, there is hypoxia in the absence of hypoxemia, i.e., arterial O2 content is normal but tissues are not able to utilize it because cyanide interferes with aerobic metabolism in the tissues.

Scenario 2:

  • Hypoxia may not be present in patients with hypoxemia if the patient compensates for a low PaO2 by increasing oxygen delivery. This is typically achieved by increasing cardiac output (by raising the heart rate) or decreasing tissue oxygen consumption.
  • Nevertheless, hypoxemia is definitely the most common cause of tissue hypoxia, and the correct diagnosis should be made because it is readily treatable.

questions.text: Which type of hypoxia does not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
In the case of anemic hypoxia, O2 content is low but dissolved O2 is within normal limits, so it does not stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors.

Peripheral chemoreceptors located in the carotid and aortic arteries sense changes in Po2(<60mm Hg), pH, and Pco2 and they respond to changes in dissolved O2(PaO2).

Histotoxic hypoxia will lead to metabolic acidosis that will lead to an increase in H+ concentration, which in turn will stimulate the peripheral chemoreceptors.

Hemorrhage that produces hypotension leads to chemoreceptor stimulation due to decreased blood flow to the chemoreceptors and consequent stagnant anoxia of these organs.

Note: In case of stagnant hypoxia, chemoreceptors can be stimulated if the resultant decreased oxygen delivery causes a significant drop in local tissue oxygen levels, which eventually can lower the PaO2 detectable by chemoreceptors. Therefore, they may not be significantly stimulated unless the reduction in oxygen levels is severe. Therefore, anaemic hypoxia is a better answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a patient with cyanosis?
questions.solution:
In stagnant hypoxia, blood flow is very low; so, more oxygen is extracted causing an increase in reduced hemoglobin → cyanosis.

Cyanosis - Cyanosis is the dusky bluish discoloration of the tissues occurring when the reduced hemoglobin concentration is more than 5g/dL.

  • Its occurrence depends upon
    • The total amount of hemoglobin in the blood
    • Degree of hemoglobin unsaturation
    • The state of capillary circulation

Option a: In the case of anemia, the total hemoglobin content is low, so enough reduced hemoglobin cannot be formed.

Option b: In histotoxic hypoxia, the amount of reduced hemoglobin formed is very less because the defect is in the tissue O2.

Option c: In CO poisoning, there is the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which is red in color obscure the color of reduced hemoglobin.

questions.text: Administration of O2 has maximum benefit in:
questions.solution:
Administration of oxygen has maximum benefit in hypoxic hypoxia.

Hypoxic hypoxia refers to a condition in which there is low atmospheric Po2, leading to low arterial Po2. Hence, supplemental O2 can be very beneficial when the cause of hypoxia is due to limited oxygen availability.

Administration of oxygen-rich gas has limited value in anemic, histotoxic, and stagnant hypoxia because:

Anemic hypoxia- Oxygen delivery is not beneficial because despite increasing the exogenous oxygen delivery, an anemic person will not have the capacity to carry more oxygen due to the hemoglobin/ red blood cell deficit in anemia.

Histotoxic hypoxia- The most common example is cyanide poisoning. Cyanide inhibits important enzymes in the oxidative phosphorylation process, which is essential to the survival of our cells. Additional oxygen supplementation will not be able to overcome this inhibition, and so it will have limited benefit. Hyperbaric oxygen may be helpful to some extent.

Stagnant hypoxia- Stagnant hypoxia refers to ischemic hypoxia that results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock. In such conditions, administering intravenous fluids can improve the patient's condition because it is the circulation that is affected. If the shock is prolonged it can result in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which can be treated with positive pressure ventilation and not simply by increasing oxygen administration.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is oxygen therapy most beneficial provided the lung function is normal?
questions.solution:
With O2 therapy, increasing the inspired Po2 will result in an increased amount of dissolved O2. At high altitudes, there is low barometric pressure and so less Po2, hence, supplemental O2 will help.

Option A: With anemia, the hemoglobin is fully saturated and O2 will have minimal effect. Treatment of anemia is more beneficial than providing oxygen to an anemic patient.

Option B: With COPD there is CO2 retention due to difficulty in the expiration, and there will be a decreased Po2. So, there is a change in the regulation of respiration (drive for ventilation) from being under CO2 control to being driven by the decrease in O2. Giving supplemental O2 to such a person will increase arterial Po2, thus decrease the stimulus to breathe, resulting in patient stopping breathing.

Option C: Cyanide poisoning results in decreased O2 utilization by the tissues and so additional O2 would be of no benefit.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful?
questions.solution:
Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression. 

High dose oxygen reduces the output of peripheral chemoreceptors. So, if given to patients who already have central respiratory depression, it will indirectly reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe even further, leading to a reduction in respiratory frequency and minute ventilation. 

Note: In acute severe asthma, a high concentration of oxygen should be given by face mask to achieve an oxygen saturation of >90%.

questions.text: Which of the points on the following figures represent arterial blood in a severely anemic person?
questions.solution: When a person is anemic, there is decrease in O2 content of the blood (Fig 1-E) because of decreased number of RBCs and hence hemoglobin content in the blood. The oxygen saturation (Fig 2-D) of the available hemoglobin in the arterial blood is however normal and, the pO2 is also not affected by the hemoglobin concentration.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is anemic with hemoglobin concentration of 6 g/dL. Which of the following set of changes have occurred in this case, compared to normal?
questions.solution:
Normal Arterial Po2, ↓Mixed venous Po2, ↑2,3-DPG are the set of changes that will be seen in the above patient.

The oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood is reduced in an anemic person, but the arterial Po2 and oxygen saturation are both normal. 

The decrease in arterial O2 content is compensated for by an increase in the extraction of oxygen from hemoglobin, which reduces the Po2 of the venous blood.

The unloading of oxygen at tissue level is enhanced by an increased level of 2,3-DPG in an anemic patient because 2,3-DPG causes a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line)?
questions.solution:
Curve C corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line). The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the left relative to the adult curve.

The fetal hemoglobin (Hb F) has a greater affinity for O2 than adult hemoglobin (Hb A). This facilitates the movement of O2 from the mother to fetus. The cause of this greater affinity is the poor binding of 2,3-DPG by ɣ polypeptide chains that replace β chains in Hb F. The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is thus shifted to the left relative to the adult curve. Typically, fetal arterial Po2 is low, hence leftward shift enhances placental uptake of O2.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood during resting conditions (dark blue line) and blood during exercise ( light blue line)?
questions.solution:
The right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve allows more oxygen to be released to the muscle at a given Po2 in the blood. The oxygen dissociation curve shifts to the right when factors like:

  1. Increased temperature resulting from heat generated by the exercising muscle,
  2. Higher carbon dioxide levels released from the muscle tissue,
  3. Elevated 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG), and
  4. Increased hydrogen ions concentration in the muscle capillary blood

Above factors decrease hemoglobin's oxygen affinity. This shift promotes easier oxygen release to muscles and other tissues.

Note: Despite the rightward shift, the maximum hemoglobin oxygen saturation at high oxygen levels remains unchanged. The plateau on the curve represents the maximal saturation achievable under optimal conditions, ensuring hemoglobin can still be fully saturated with oxygen.

Decompression sickness is seen in pilots, mountaineers, and divers.

Decompression sickness (DCS) or diver’s disease, the bends, or Caisson disease is the name given to a variety of symptoms experienced by a person exposed to a reduction in the pressure surrounding their body.

It can be seen in

  • Divers ascending rapidly from deep-sea (high pressure) to the surface of the earth (low pressure) 
  • Pilots traveling in unpressurized aircraft or mountaineers, rapidly ascending from the surface of the earth (high-pressure zone) to a high altitude (low-pressure zone).

Under high-pressure, gases get compressed and their solubility increases. When a person is in a high-pressure zone like the deep sea for a long time, an increased amount of nitrogen gets dissolved in his or her body. If the person suddenly comes back to an area of atmospheric pressure or a low-pressure zone, the gases escape from a dissolved state and form bubbles. These bubbles are almost entirely made of nitrogen. The bubbles can plug many small blood vessels in different tissues.

choices.text: Increased solubility of nitrogen in nerve cell

questions.solution:
Nitrogen narcosis is due to increased solubility of nitrogen in the nerve cell.

Concept:

  • Below the sea level, atmospheric pressure increases at the rate of 1 atm for every 33 feet depth.
  • According to Boyle’s law, as pressure increases, volume decreases. Hence, lungs tend to collapse. To prevent this and to keep lung expanded, gas is delivered at high pressure to the lungs.
  • According to Dalton’s law, nitrogen contributes the maximum to barometric pressure and hence the amount of nitrogen entering alveoli increases.
  • Henry’s law: As the partial pressure of nitrogen in alveoli increases, its concentration in blood also increases (dissolved form). Nitrogen is 5 times more soluble in fat compared to water.
  • As a result, nitrogen dissolves in the fatty substances in neuronal membranes, and because of its physical effect on altering ionic conductance through the membranes, it reduces neuronal excitability and produces the narcotic effect.

This was a recent AIIMS question. Nitrogen narcosis has characteristics similar to those of alcohol intoxication, and for this reason, it has frequently been called raptures of the depths.

questions.text: During acclimatization at higher altitude, all of the following changes take place except ______.

choices.text: Shift of Oxygen Haemoglobin Dissociation Curve to left

questions.solution:
A shift of Oxygen Haemoglobin Dissociation Curve (OHDC) to the right is seen in acclimatization.

On ascension to higher altitudes over a period of days rather than a period of hours, the ability to breathe much more deeply and withstand lower atmospheric O2 concentrations is improved. This phenomenon is called acclimatization.

Variation of pH in Acclimatization:

Immediate exposure to low pO2 stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors. This increases alveolar ventilation. This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the pCO2 and increases the pH of the body fluids.

These changes inhibit the brain stem respiratory center and thereby oppose the effect of low PO2 to stimulate respiration through the peripheral arterial chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies.

There is a reduction of bicarbonate ion concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid, as well as in the brain tissues. This reduction, in turn, decreases the pH in the fluids surrounding the chemosensitive neurons of the respiratory center, thus increasing the respiratory stimulatory activity of the center. An important mechanism for the gradual decrease in bicarbonate concentration is compensation by the kidneys for the respiratory alkalosis. Gradually, the metabolic compensation of the kidney will shift the pH towards normal.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of headache and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness and IV digoxin is not used to treat this condition. 

On ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and the following symptoms are seen:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high altitude areas
